page.title: 04Sheep Farming on Horse-Eye
page.content: On Horse-Eye Level, mainly a flat area there are 2 types of animal farming. One is sheep, the other being cattle. The type of sheep that graze on the marshland are Southdown & Romney Marsh. They are reared for their wool as well as for their meat. The lambing season in the 1980s is now anytime from late autumn to mid spring. The ewes are taken in during lambing time in order to prevent, where possible, problems arising from multiple births. Modern day farming having to be cost effective, loss of stock at birth - 3 lambs being not unusual - cannot be tolerated. Depending on weather conditions the ewes with their new lambs are turned back out on the marshes anything from 24 hrs to 7 days after their birth. Only in very extreme weather conditions are the sheep taken in.
